PAL.NAME: Microsoft Lync Server 2013 - Front End
PAL.DESCRIPTION: Performance counter thresholds for Microsoft Lync Server 2013 Front End Server.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - DBStore\USrv - Queue Latency USrv - Queue Latency (msec)
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Queue latency is the amount of time (in milliseconds) that it takes for a request to leave the Front End Server’s queue toward the back-end database.
If this value by itself is high, you may have be encountering a network problem between FE->SQL.
If this value is high and Sproc Latency is high, it is most commonly a bottom-neck with the SQL backend.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - DBStore\USrv - Sproc Latency USrv - Sproc Latency (msec)
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION:
Sproc latency is the amount of time (in milliseconds) that it takes for the Microsoft® SQL Server® data management software database to process the request. This performance value is collected from the time the request leaves the Front End Server queue until that the request returns.
If this value by itself is high, it is likely a bottleneck with the SQL backend.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - REGDBStore\USrv - Sproc Latency USrv - Sproc Latency (msec)
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time (in milliseconds) it takes to execute a sproc call.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:USrv - DBStore USrv - Throttled requests/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of requests that were rejected/sec with a retry-after since the database queue latency was high.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Peers SIP - Sends Timed-Out/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The per-second rate of sends dropped because they stayed in outgoing (send) queue for too long.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Responses SIP - Local 503 Responses/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The per-second rate of 503 responses generated by the server.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Peers SIP - Average Outgoing Queue Delay
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time (in seconds) the messages delayed in outgoing (send) queues.

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Peers SIP - Flow-controlled Connections
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The number of connections that are currently being flow-controlled (no socket receives are posted).

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Protocol SIP - Incoming Requests Dropped/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The per-second rate of incoming requests dropped because they could not be processed (due to bad headers, insufficient routing information, server resource allocation failure).

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Protocol SIP - Incoming Responses Dropped/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The per-second rate of incoming responses dropped because they could not be processed (due to bad headers, insufficient routing information, server resource allocation failure).

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Protocol SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time (in seconds) it takes to process an incoming message.

DATASOURCE.NAME: \LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time
DATASOURCE.EXPRESSIONPATH: \LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time

CHART.CHARTTITLE: \LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time
CHART.DATASOURCE: \LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Authentication SIP - Authentication System Errors/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The per-second rate of authentication failures caused by system errors (due to low memory conditions or otherwise).

ANALYSIS.NAME: LS:SIP - Load Management SIP - Average Holding Time For Incoming Messages
ANALYSIS.PRIMARYDATASOURCE: \LS:SIP - Load Management\SIP - Average Holding Time For Incoming Messages
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: The average time that the server held the incoming messages currently being processed.

DATASOURCE.NAME: \LS:SIP - Load Management\SIP - Average Holding Time For Incoming Messages

THRESHOLD.NAME: Current percentage of space used by Storage Service DB. >= 80

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Current percentage of space used by Storage Service DB.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$LYNCLOCAL:Buffer Manager Page life expectancy
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Tells, on average, how many seconds SQL Server expects a data page to stay in cache. The target on an OLTP system should be at least 300 (5 min). When under 300, this may indicate poor index design (leading to increased disk I/O and less effective use of memory) or, simply, a potential shortage of memory. A low value, below 3600 seconds (together with high lazy writes/sec and checkpoint pages/sec) indicates memory pressure.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$LYNCLOCAL:Memory Manager\Total Server Memory Total Server Memory (KB)
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the amount of memory that SQL Server is currently using. This value should grow until its equal to Target Server Memory, as it populates its caches and loads pages into memory. When it has finished, SQL Server is said to be in a “steady-state”. Until it is in steady-state, performance may be slow and IO may be higher. 'what SQL has'

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$LYNCLOCAL:Memory Manager\Target Server Memory Target Server Memory (KB)
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the amount of memory that SQL Server wants to use based on the configured Max Server Memory. It represents the ideal number of pages in the buffer pool. It is the amount of memory that can be committed without causing paging. 'what SQL wants'

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$LYNCLOCAL:Memory Manager Memory Grants Pending
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Total number of processes per second waiting for a workspace memory grant. Numbers higher than 0 indicate a lack of memory.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$LYNCLOCAL:SQL Statistics Batch Requests/sec
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Number of batch requests received per second, and is a good general indicator for the activity level of the SQL Server. This counter is highly dependent on the hardware and quality of code running on the server. The more powerful the hardware, the higher this number can be, even on poorly coded applications. A value of 1000 batch requests/sec is easily attainable though a typical 100Mbs NIC can only handle about 3000 batch requests/sec.Many other counter thresholds depend upon batch requests/sec while, in some cases, a low (or high) number does not point to poor processing power. You should frequently use this counter in combination with other counters, such as processor utilization or user connections.In version 2000, “Transactions/ sec” was the counter most often used to measure overall activity, while versions 2005 and later use “Batch Requests/sec”. Versions 2005 prior to SP2, measure this counter differently and may lead to some misunderstandings.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$RTC:Buffer Manager Page life expectancy
ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Tells, on average, how many seconds SQL Server expects a data page to stay in cache. The target on an OLTP system should be at least 300 (5 min). When under 300, this may indicate poor index design (leading to increased disk I/O and less effective use of memory) or, simply, a potential shortage of memory. A low value, below 3600 seconds (together with high lazy writes/sec and checkpoint pages/sec) indicates memory pressure.

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$RTC:Memory Manager\Total Server Memory Total Server Memory (KB)

Until it is in steady-state, performance may be slow and IO may be higher. 'what SQL has'

ANALYSIS.DESCRIPTION: Shows the amount of memory that SQL Server wants to use based on the configured Max Server Memory. It represents the ideal number of pages in the buffer pool. It is the amount of memory that can be committed without causing paging. 'what SQL wants'

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$RTC:Memory Manager Memory Grants Pending

ANALYSIS.NAME: MSSQL$RTC:SQL Statistics Batch Requests/sec

This counter is highly dependent on the hardware and quality of code running on the server. The more powerful the hardware, the higher this number can be, even on poorly coded applications. A value of 1000 batch requests/sec is easily attainable though a typical 100Mbs NIC can only handle about 3000 batch requests/sec.Many other counter thresholds depend upon batch requests/sec while, in some cases, a low (or high) number does not point to poor processing power. You should frequently use this counter in combination with other counters, such as processor utilization or user connections.In version 2000, “Transactions/ sec” was the counter most often used to measure overall activity, while versions 2005 and later use “Batch Requests/sec”. Versions 2005 prior to SP2, measure this counter differently and may lead to some misunderstandings.
